title-group.article-title: Perceiving and Representing Slavery and "Race" "Through" Time: William Faulkner's "Absalom, Absalom!"

abstract.p: Taking issue with a prevalent tendency in literary criticism that reduces fictional texts to what is construed as an inevitable and constitutive complicity with the discourse of power, this essay investigates the ways in which William Faulkner's Absalom, Absalom! criticizes and affirms slavery and "racial" difference simultaneously by doubling the perspective on discursive structures through narrative and rhetorical strategies. The central argument is that time is one of the crucial factors through which not only the history of slavery, but also representations of relations between Self and Other are constructed. Drawing on hermeneutic thought, the concept of alterity is discussed on two levels, historical and cultural, as well as applied practically to a reading of the encounter between Miss Rosa and Clytie. Temporal distancing is shown to be used as a device through which white characters exclude African Americans, a mechanism, nevertheless, that reaches back to them with a recursive and retroactive effect. Faulkner's novel stages the ways in which white Southerners are affected by the ideology of "racial" difference.
